Unworthy talk engaged by Nigrodha and hi: Talk about kings, bandits, and ministers
Talk about armies, threats, and wars
Talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds
Talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries
Talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence
Nigrodha's challenge to the Buddha (a de: Nigrodha challenges the Buddha to come to his assembly
Nigrodha plans to ask the Buddha a question
The question is "Sir, what teaching do you use to guide your disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life?"
The conditions for the mortification in: Going naked, ignoring conventions
Licking hands, not coming or waiting when called
Not consenting to food brought to them, or food prepared on purpose for them, or an invitation for a meal

Not receiving anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breast-feeding, or who has a man in her home; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing
Accepting no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drinking no beer
Going to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls
Feeding on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day
Eating once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight
Living committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals
Eating herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung
Surviving on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit
Wearing robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings
Tearing out their hair and beard, committed to this practice
Constantly standing, refusing seats
Squatting, committed to persisting in the squatting position
Lying on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed
Making their bed on a plank, or the bare ground
Lying only on one side
Wearing dust and dirt
Staying in the open air
Sleeping wherever they lay their mat
Eating unnatural things, committed to the practice of eating unnatural foods
Not drinking, committed to the practice of not drinking liquids
Being committed to the practice of immersion in water three times a day, including the evening.

Glorifying themselves and putting others down on account of that

Generating possessions, honor, and popularity through that mortification and glorifying themselves and putting others down on account of that

Becoming fussy about food and eating tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape
Undertaking a practice of mortification out of longing for possessions, honor, and popularity, thinking that they will be honored by others
Rebuking a certain ascetic or brahmin
Giving rise to jealousy and stinginess regarding families
Sitting meditation only when people can see them
Disagreeing with the way that the Realized One or their disciple teaches Dhamma, even when they make a valid point

Being irritable and hostile, offensive and contemptuous, jealous and stingy, devious and deceitful, obstinate and vain, having wicked desires, falling under the sway of wicked desires, having wrong view, being attached to an extremist view, and being attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.

Not generating possessions, honor, and popularity through mortification
Not undertaking a practice of mortification out of longing for possessions, honor, and popularity
Not rebuking a certain ascetic or brahmin

Not being irritable and hostile, offensive and contemptuous, jealous and stingy, devious and deceitful, obstinate and vain, having wicked desires, and wrong view, and not being attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.

Mortification in disgust of sin has not yet reached the peak and the pith, but only reached the shoots.
The fourfold restraint [dn25:16.0]: They don’t kill living creatures, get others to kill, or approve of killing.
They don’t steal, get others to steal, or approve of stealing.
They don’t lie, get others to lie, or approve of lying.
They don’t expect rewards from their practice, they don’t lead others to expect rewards, and they don’t approve of expecting rewards.

Giving up ill will and malevolence
Spreading a heart full of love
Spreading a heart full of compassion
Spreading a heart full of rejoicing
Spreading a heart full of equanimity

Recollecting many kinds of past lives

Recollecting many eons of the world contracting
Recollecting many eons of the world expanding
Recollecting many eons of the world contracting and expanding
Recollecting the details of past lives, including name, clan, appearance, food, pleasure, pain, and how life ended.

The questions asked by Sandhāna to Nigro: Why don’t you send him out of the assembly to the periphery like a nilgai antelope?
Why don’t you sink him with just one question?
Why don’t you roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot?
The behavior of the Buddhas of the past: They frequented remote lodgings in the wilderness
The lodgings were quiet and still
The lodgings were far from the madding crowd
The lodgings were remote from human settlements
The lodgings were fit for retreat
The qualities of the Buddha (a causal se: Teaches Dhamma for awakening, taming, serenity, crossing over, and extinguishment
The teaching and instruction of the Budd: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life
Reasons why the ascetic Gotama speaks in: Because he wants them to give up their recitation
Because he wants them to give up their livelihood
Because he wants them to start doing things that are unskillful and considered unskillful in their tradition
Because he wants them to stop doing things that are skillful and considered skillful in their tradition
Things that may be given up through the: Things that lead to future lives
Things that result in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death
The thoughts of the Buddha [dn25:23.0]: All these foolish people have been touched by the Wicked One!
For not even a single one thinks, ‘Come, let us lead the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama for the sake of enlightenment—for what do seven days matter?’”
